I.  THE ONGOING PROGRAM  
 
1.  Seismic Safety Improvement Program (SSIP), first results-based lending program (RBL 
program) in Armenia was approved on 22 September 2015 with an amount of $88.5 million. The 
RBL program supports the implementation of the National Strategy for Disaster Risk Reduction1 
by (i) improving school seismic safety to reduce casualties and damage in schools during 
earthquakes, and (ii) enabling better use of school buildings as shelters for the general public and 
as focal points for emergency response after earthquakes. SSIP is part of a wider government 
program to strengthen schools that are seismically vulnerable. The outcome of the Program is 
improved coverage of seismically safe school buildings through increased number of students 
studying in school buildings meeting the safety standards for MSK 9(IX) scale earthquakes by 5.3 
percentage points from the baseline. The four results areas of SSIP include: i) increasing seismic 
resilience of school buildings; ii) strengthening seismic disaster preparedness and response 
capacity; iii) improving supportive policies and systems for seismic disaster risk management and 
reduction; and iv) enhancing national capacity in executing and implementing the seismic safety 
investment programs. SSIP will reconstruct or retrofit at least 46 priority school buildings. The 
loan closing date was originally envisaged on 31 May 2021 but has since been extended to 31 
May 2024 due to start up delays and government’s budget consolidation.  
 
2.  A knowledge and support technical assistance (KSTA)2 for $800,000 was approved to 
support the implementation of SSIP. The KSTA has helped to build capacity during the first three 
years of the implementation and after two extensions it is scheduled to close on 30 September 
2019. As of 30 October 2018, cumulative disbursements from the TA is $418,227. As of 30 
September 2018, the RBL program reached 34% of the lapsed time, 12% physical progress, and 
9.3% financial progress. The first advance payment of $21.95 million was disbursed in December 
2015. Based on the achieved disbursement-linked indicators (DLIs) an additional $3.8 million was 
disbursed in December 2016. As of 30 September 2018, cumulative spending by the IA from the 
loan special account is $6.4 million. The executing agency (EA) is the Ministry of Territorial 
Administration and Development (MTAD) and the implementing agency (IA) is the Armenian 
Territorial Development Fund (ATDF).  
 
3.  The verification protocol of SSIP requires that the construction completion report of 
schools shall be validated by an internationally accredited third party in terms of its compliance 
with the MSK9 (IX) scale earthquake safety requirements. Validation of the constructed and 
retrofitted schools by the accredited third party is an important condition for disbursement of the 
SSIP funds, and endorsement of the detailed design of schools is a key technical milestone. The 
Government  of  Armenia  has  requested  ADB to  provide  continuous  support to  design  and 
construction of SSIP schools and to cover the costs of validations using TA resources. 
 
II.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
 
A.  Justification 
 
4.  The transaction TA (TRTA) will help the EA and IA develop the capacity to implement the 
SSIP and to validate the achievements of DLI targets. The TRTA will have two components: i) 
engineering support for design and reconstruction/retrofitting of program schools, and ii) validation 
of selected DLIs. The first component is justified by the specialized nature of skills required for 
building schools with targeted seismic intensity and lack of local engineering and construction

and impossible. The support will be provided after 30 September 2019, the extended date of the

ADB TA will help to ensure independent validation and to avoid the risks of delay associated with 
the government’s fiscal constraints.  
 
5.  The TA is included in the country operations business plan (COBP) 2019–2021 for 
approval in 2018.  
   
B.  Outputs and Activities 
 
6.  Output 1: Quality of Design and Construction Verified and Improved. The activity will 
strengthen quality of design and construction of seismic resilient schools. While the detailed 
design will be financed by the loan, it needs to be verified by the consultant to meet the targeted 
standards. Considering the weak local capacity, this would be important to comply with SSIP 
requirements and avoid failure in validation. Consultant’s periodic visits to the construction sites 
will be conducted to inspect the quality of works. The support will be extended throughout SSIP 
implementation with relatively heavy inputs during the first-three years of implementation, and 
fewer inputs closer to completion.   
 
7.  Output 2: About 46 schools with school buildings meeting the safety standards in 
Armenia for MSK 9 (IX) scale earthquake validated. The output will focus on validation of 
completed schools through field visits and reviews of design and construction documents and 
reports. A methodology and framework of construction validation will be developed at an early 
stage. The validation will be conducted throughout SSIP implementation.      
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
 
8.  The TA is estimated to cost $550,000, of which $500,000 will be financed on a grant basis 
by ADB’s Technical Assistance Special Fund (TASF-other sources) and $50,000 is the value of 
the government's in-kind contribution. The key expenditure items are listed in Appendix 1.  
 
9.  Eligible  expenditures  include  (i)  consultant  services  for  capacity  building,  and  (ii) 
consultant services for validation of selected SSIP DLIs.  
 
10.  The government will provide counterpart support in the form of counterpart staff, domestic 
land transportation, per diem of national consultants, office space and office supplies, laboratory 
analysis costs, secretarial assistance, and other in-kind contributions.

and evaluate consultants. The Ministry of Territorial Administration and Development will be the 
executing agency. The TRTA will be implemented from December 2018 to December 2023.

TERMS OF REFERENCE FOR CONSULTANTS 
 
A.  Introduction  
1.   The Seismic Safety Improvement Program (SSIP) is the ADB loan to Armenia designed 
using results-based lending (RBL) modality. The $88.5 million program aims to increase the 
number of students studying in school buildings meeting the safety standards for MSK 9(IX) scale 
earthquakes by 5.3 percentage points from the baseline.  The program has four results areas. 
Results area 1: Increasing seismic resilience of school buildings. The program will support 
the strengthening or reconstruction of at least 46 priority school buildings identified by the 
Government.  The strengthened or reconstructed school buildings will meet the internationally 
accepted seismic safety standards for an earthquake of Medvedev-Sponheuer- Karnik (MSK) 
scale IX. Results area 2: Strengthening seismic disaster preparedness and response 
capacity.  An  emergency  response  action  plan  will  be  developed  for each  school  building 
strengthened or reconstructed under the program and will further raise the students’ and teachers’ 
awareness on seismic risks and to guide them in properly responding and evacuating in the event 
of earthquakes. Results area 3: Improving supportive policies and systems for seismic 
disaster risk management and reduction. The program will support (a) the review and update 
of the country’s building codes for schools so they are harmonized with international standards 
for seismic safety, (b) development of guidelines for school building strengthening and retrofitting 
in line with international best practices, (c) consolidate and update of the governments broader 
program for school strengthening and reconstruction (SSRP), and (d) update of the probabilistic 
seismic  hazard  map.  Results  area  4:  Enhancing  national  capacity  in  executing  and 
implementing the seismic safety investment programs. The program will strengthen the 
Armenian Territorial Development Fund (ATDF) for effective implementation of the program.  
 
2.  Based  on  the  four  results  areas  disbursement  linked  indicators  (DLIs)  have  been 
developed. Disbursements under the program are linked to successful achievement of DLIs. The 
program documents are accessible from the following URL4. Program DLIs and DLI verification 
protocol  are  in  Attachment  1.  Validation  of  the  constructed  and  retrofitted  schools  by  the 
accredited  third  party  is  an  important  condition  for  disbursement  of  the  SSIP  funds,  and 
endorsement of the detailed design of schools, is a key technical milestone. 
 
3.  The executing agency (EA) is the Ministry of Territorial Administration and Development 
(MTAD) and the implementing agency (IA) is the Armenian Territorial Development Fund (ATDF). 
The program completion is scheduled for 30 November 2023. 
 
4.   ADB will provide to the Government of Armenia a technical assistance (TA) grant to support 
effective implementation of SSIP. With two consulting packages the TA will: i) support for 
improving supportive policies and systems for seismic disaster risk reduction, and support for 
designing and constructing school buildings with targeted seismic intensity (Package 1), and ii) 
conduct independent validation of DLI achievement (Package 2).

5.  The scope will focus on strengthening the quality of design and construction of seismic

14.  According to loan agreement ATDF prepares an attestation that DLI is met and attaches 
the M&E reports and construction completion reports validated by the consulting firm in terms of 
its compliance with the MSK 9 (IX) scale earthquake safety requirements.  
15.   Schools under SSIP project have been designed for peak ground acceleration of 0.4g and 
importance factor 1.3. Therefore, the compliance with the MSK 9 (IX) scale earthquake safety 
requirements is considered achieved if the building is built according to design. 
 
16.  The  validation  includes  both  structural  and  non-structural  components.  During  the 
inception stage of the contract the consulting firm will propose a good-practice methodology for 
the  validation  and  a template  which  will  be  agreed  in  advance  with ADB  and  Package  1 
consultants. The validation will be conducted by the relevant experts on call-off basis at agreed 
time periods during the contract. DLIs have annual targets and will be reviewed in groups 
biennially or at specific agreed achievement dates. The validation will be undertaken during 
country visits (missions) by the firm on dates pre-agreed with ADB and ATDF. 
 
17.  The validation will be conducted in two phases: i) phase 1 – preliminary validation (phase 
1) will be conducted after completion of the structural part of the building. In cases where the 
requirement has been only partially achieved or has not been achieved, the necessary guidance 
on requirements to achieve the same will be provided, and ii) final validation (phase 2) will be 
conducted  after  completion  of  construction.  The  validation  will  be  conducted  by  reviewing 
documents provided by ATDF as well as assessment of other data as relevant and by conducting 
field visits/inspections. During the validation the firm will consult with international consultants 
hired under the Package 1.  
 
18.  The firm’s opinion will be supported by review and analysis of the documents and include 
clear reasoning for the validation decision for each school. The validation report and all other 
documents prepared by the firm will be in English.

22.  Safety Features Engineer: (national, 4.1 home and 4.1 field person-months intermittently 
over 58 months). The consultant will have a civil engineering/mechanical engineering degree 
(master’s degree preferred) with at least 10 years of experience with non-structural/mechanical 
component design and construction of earthquake resistant or strengthened buildings and/or 
retrofitted buildings and structures in seismic area. Experience with the Armenia building codes 
and seismic resilient construction norms is required. Experience with international development 
agencies, such as UNICEF, World Bank, ADB, is preferred. The consultant must have English 
communication skills. The consultant will:  
 
(i)  Review the methodology for verifying that safety features meet the 
requirements for standing seismic event of targeted intensity. The 
methodology is developed under the program. 
(ii)  Review the construction documentation and conduct Phase 2 validation field 
visits upon completion of the school buildings to verify & endorse compliance 
of safety features for standing seismic event of targeted intensity against the 
checklist of safety features.  
(iii)  In cases where the requirement has been only partially achieved or has not 
been achieved, provide the necessary and practical guidance to achieve the 
targeted safety requirements; 
(iv)  Issue a safety features compliance report in an agreed format.
